work_done: Led the migration of a monolithic EOD loan processing system to a scalable, distributed microservices architecture, improving system reliability and scalability to handle millions of records.
Implemented Kafka-based event-driven architecture for real-time message handling, ensuring efficient batch processing and fault tolerance.
Designed and implemented batch processing strategies, dividing large loan records into smaller batches and ensuring high parallelism across microservices.
Developed a robust retry mechanism with exponential backoff and Dead Letter Queue (DLQ) integration for handling message processing failures and ensuring data integrity.
Optimized consumer offset management in Kafka to prevent message loss and duplication, ensuring idempotent and reliable processing.
Automated failure detection and recovery by integrating monitoring systems and alerts to track processing statuses and trigger manual intervention when needed.
Improved database interaction by partitioning loan records and optimizing queries, reducing load on the monolithic database.
Deployed microservices on a containerized infrastructure using Docker and Kubernetes, ensuring high availability and fault tolerance.
Enhanced real-time data processing performance by implementing timeouts, rate limiting, and resource scaling techniques to prevent bottlenecks.
Developed APIs and services to enable smooth interaction between workers and the message queue, facilitating seamless batch processing.
Increased system throughput and reduced processing time by leveraging parallel processing and distributing workload across multiple services.
Ensured compliance with industry standards for financial data handling and processing, maintaining accuracy and consistency across the system.
